title: Copenhagen: a guide to the best shops, hotels and restaurants
text:
City breaks Copenhagen: a guide to the best shops, hotels and restaurants From Scandi design to champagne cocktails and mystery menus… the Danish city has so much more to offer visitors than little mermaids and big wheels The waterfront at Nyhavn Photo: Alamy By Rachael Dove Comments Stay 
Even though the Moorish-style Nimb Hotel is in the gardens of Tivoli – one of the world’s oldest theme parks – its 17 rooms have a palatial calm. Even better, each comes impeccably furnished with a four-poster bed. From £265 
A stone’s throw from Nyhavn, Copenhagen’s picturesque waterfront, Hotel d’Angleterre is an elegant mix of contemporary (modern artworks in the rooms) and classic (chandeliers in the lobby). The minimalist basement spa is the icing on the cake. From £285 
Handily located a short walk from both the central train station and the city’s cool meatpacking district, the Andersen is bright and roomy with a helpful concierge and handybicycle hire. From £107 
The Moorish-style Nimb Hotel Eat 
Run by two former Noma chefs, Bror is a showcase of innovation. On the mystery four-course menu, which changes daily, expect dishes such as cod head, ox heart and tarragon ice cream. 
With big windows and light, artistic dishes, Atelier September is an Instagrammer’s dream. Fresh herbs and edible flowers – foraged and dropped off daily by a local architect on his way to work – punctuate each dish. 
There is a distinct New York vibe about the meatpacking district’s Gorilla : great cocktails, impeccable service and a pared-back interior. Highlights include Hiddenfjord salmon. 
Cool dining at Bror Drink 
Made with fresh fruit and champagnes from more than 40 producers, the cocktails at Balthazar Champagne Bar at the Hotel d’Angleterre draw a sophisticated crowd. Book a table to avoid the throngs at the bar. Shop 
With just two small floors, interiors store Munk Shop is a lesson in modern Scandi design. Find cool light-fittings from the Danish brand Frama and Swedish name Orsjö Belysning. 
Ceramic artist Inge Vincents sells paper-thin cups, vases and bowls in her studio at friendly prices. 
Local designer Henrik Vibskov’s eponymous boutique sells his functional collection, as well as pieces from designers including Chalayan and Asli Filinta.

A 35-minute train ride out of the city, the Louisiana Museum of Modern Art has a vast permanent collection and grounds that look over the Baltic Sea. 
Taste some of the best food the city has to offer at Torvehallerne market. Find Paleo wraps, organic veg stalls and micro-roastery coffee beans. Fly with 
EasyJet flies to Copenhagen from London Luton up to four times a day; fares from £23.49 one way
